subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] On a keyboard
messageBody:
amd64_hacker wrote:

http://www.pckeyboa rd.com/Kustomizi ng.html - The site of Unicomp.
They inherited the Model M, the classic PC keyboard, from IBM.
They're a bit costly but they last forever.
They want 'certain volume requirements' for 'unique keyboards' though.

Does anyone else know of any other custom keyboard manufacturers?
What sort of layout should a QS keyboard have anyway?

tim_rice09 wrote:
>
> The keyboard that we use now was designed for a 26 letter alphabet
> and the current way to write Quickscript uses the shift keys about as
> much as the spacebar. Not to mention the backspace key takes a finger
> contortionism to use.
> A possible answer to this, build a new keyboard that may not even
> have to have a shift key.
>
>

There is another possibility, which essentially uses another key as the "shift" key.  For example, "j" combined with a following letter on a mapped keyboard to shift to another letter.  This works better than using the shift key all the time because your right forefinger is over the "j" so it is faster to hit it than to go to the shift key.  It also makes more sense to me than attempting to have a new keyboard manufactured.  I cannot believe that would cost effective for a very long time, i.e. until we need a lot more keyboards than we would at present.  The other problem with that is that people aren't always at the same computer.  Since a newly  designed keyboard would be a big change from the standard we are used to, I wonder how that would affect touch typing speed?
























Paige
